title: Identifying Executive Skill Strengths and Weaknesses
summary: Assess and recognize which executive skills are strong and which need improvement.

details.content: Understanding your unique executive skill profile helps target interventions and build on strengths while addressing weaknesses.
A parent and child complete a checklist to identify that the child is strong in planning but struggles with organization and emotional control.

content: Use self-assessment tools or checklists from the book.
Discuss results openly and non-judgmentally.
Revisit assessments periodically to track progress.

title: Creating Routines and Structures
summary: Establish predictable routines and clear structures to support executive functioning.

details.content: Consistent routines reduce cognitive load, making it easier to remember tasks and manage time.
A morning checklist helps a child remember to brush teeth, pack lunch, and gather homework before school.

content: Start with one routine at a time (e.g., bedtime or homework).
Use visual schedules or written lists.
Review and adjust routines as needed.

title: Setting Goals and Providing Incentives
summary: Help children set achievable goals and use incentives to motivate progress.

details.content: Clear goals and rewards increase motivation and provide a sense of accomplishment.
A child earns extra screen time for completing homework before dinner three days in a row.

content: Set specific, measurable, and realistic goals.
Choose meaningful incentives.
Celebrate small successes to build momentum.

title: Teaching Problem-Solving Skills
summary: Guide children through a step-by-step process to solve problems independently.

details.content: Problem-solving skills foster independence and resilience when facing challenges.
A child uses a problem-solving worksheet to brainstorm solutions when they forget their homework.

content: Model the problem-solving process out loud.
Break down problems into manageable steps.
Encourage brainstorming multiple solutions.

title: Using Visual Aids and Checklists
summary: Support memory and organization with visual reminders and checklists.

details.content: Visual supports reduce reliance on working memory and help track tasks.
A laminated checklist by the door reminds a child to pack their backpack, lunch, and water bottle.

content: Create simple, colorful checklists for daily routines.
Use pictures for younger children.
Update checklists as routines change.

title: Managing Time Effectively
summary: Teach strategies for estimating, allocating, and tracking time for tasks.

details.content: Time management skills help prevent last-minute rushes and reduce stress.
A child uses a timer to break homework into 20-minute work sessions with short breaks.

content: Use timers or alarms to signal transitions.
Practice estimating how long tasks will take.
Encourage use of planners or calendars.

title: Building Emotional Control and Flexibility
summary: Develop strategies to manage emotions and adapt to changes or setbacks.

details.content: Emotional regulation and flexibility are key for coping with frustration and unexpected events.
A child practices deep breathing when upset and learns to adjust plans when a playdate is canceled.

content: Teach and model calming techniques (e.g., deep breathing, counting to ten).
Discuss alternative plans when things change.
Praise efforts to stay calm and adapt.
